I've been following this thread with some amusement that someone hasn't said
the obvious.

If you don't know how to test the method then you don't understand the
method.

For instance, if I know I am going to have a setter that simple sets a
variable and the
getter that returns it, then the method mentioned before of:

	o.setThing( aThing );
	assertEquals( aThing, o.getThing());

Works real well.

But If you have a more complex set/get combination such as a getter that
returns a clone 
of the variable then you would want something like:

	Point p = new Point(99,99);
	o.setPoint( p );
	assert( "Better not be same point object", p != o.getPoint());
	assertEquals("But better have same x,y", p, o.getPoint());


As J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger said, "do not test what cannot possibly break."
so you don't
really need to test the simple set/get combination. But by the same token,
make sure
that you really need the simple set/get combination. Don't add them simply
because you
think you might need them someday. Add them because a test you are writing
shows a need
for them.
